message_1:
Here's a precise numerical problem based on Modal Logic:

Let S = {1, 2, 3} be the set of possible worlds in a modal logic system. Let R be a binary relation on the set S defined by R = {(1, 2), (2, 1), (2, 3)}. That is, R holds between the worlds 1 and 2, 2 and 1, and 2 and 3. Let φ be the formula (□p ∧ ¬◊q) where p and q are propositional variables. 

Determine which worlds in S satisfy the formula φ under the accessibility relation R.
message_2:
To determine which worlds in S satisfy the formula φ under the accessibility relation R, we need to evaluate the formula (□p ∧ ¬◊q) for each world in S.

Recall that □p means "p is true in all accessible worlds" and ◊q means "q is true in at least one accessible world."

1. World 1:
Accessible worlds: {2}
□p: p must be true in world 2.
¬◊q: q must be false in all accessible worlds, i.e., world 2.

2. World 2:
Accessible worlds: {1, 3}
□p: p must be true in worlds 1 and 3.
¬◊q: q must be false in all accessible worlds, i.e., worlds 1 and 3.

3. World 3:
Accessible worlds: {}
□p: There are no accessible worlds, so p is vacuously true in all accessible worlds.
¬◊q: There are no accessible worlds, so q is vacuously false in all accessible worlds.

Now, we need to determine which worlds satisfy both conditions (□p ∧ ¬◊q).

World 1: To satisfy φ, p must be true in world 2 and q must be false in world 2. We don't have enough information to determine if this is the case, so we cannot conclude that world 1 satisfies φ.

World 2: To satisfy φ, p must be true in worlds 1 and 3, and q must be false in worlds 1 and 3. We don't have enough information to determine if this is the case, so we cannot conclude that world 2 satisfies φ.

World 3: Since there are no accessible worlds, both □p and ¬◊q are vacuously true. Therefore, world 3 satisfies φ.

In conclusion, only world 3 satisfies the formula φ under the accessibility relation R.
